messageBody:
Java Tools for Extreme Programming (covers JUnit, Cactus, JUnitPerf,
HttpUnit, etc.) was just reviewed on JavaRanch.

It received a very good review (9 out of 10).

Frank Carver (the reviewer) says, "This book was almost too useful to
review... Everyone I've shown it to has wanted their own copy"

The book has several chapters on JUnit not to mention JUnit, HTTPUnit,
Cactus, Ant and more.

For the complete review from Frank Carver go to:
http://www.javaranch.com/cgi-bin/ubb/ultimatebb.cgi?ubb=get_topic&f=49&t=000
191


If you have any comments on the book, there is a forum on JavaRanch at:
http://www.javaranch.com/cgi-bin/ubb/ultimatebb.cgi?ubb=get_topic&f=49&t=000
191

Please share you experiences with the book or share you experiences with
using the tools (JUnit, Ant, et al) to do automated testing and continuous
integration.

A small comment about the review...

I agree with Frank that the book is for more than just developers that are
doing XP (XPers). I state this several times in the book. However, IÂ’d like
to add...

If you are following the XP development process and you are doing J2EE
development, then you especially need the tools described in this book. This
is because XP relies heavily on automated testing, and continuous
integration. JUnit, which is heavily covered in this book, was designed and
co-created by the father of the XP process--Kent Beck.

Here is what one J2EE XP developer wrote about the book...

"I have been struggling with turning XP methodology into a solid development
process. We've had some success at my company but most times we've met
frustrations primarily because we were trying to teach old tools new
tricks."

"Java Tools for XP has made a big difference for us. My team has been able
to use the tools described in this book to actually DO unit testing, and
we've already automated a significant portion of our testing and deployment
processes. Its also let us make a good case for open source tools at my
company."

"Overall I definitely recommend this book as the first book to make XP
real."

I receive a lot of email that states similar things. If you are doing XP and
Java (especially J2EE), then the tools described in this book are essential.

Thanks again.

Rick Hightower
Director of Development
eBlox, Inc.
